member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Synchronize(System.String,System.String,EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPSyncRules)
member.summary: Synchronizes the given local directory with the given remote directory according to the given synchronization rules.

remarks.para: Synchronization aims to ensure that the files in a directory on the local machine match those in a directory on the remote machine.

The instructions contained in inform the synchronization process how files should be matched. If these rules are insufficient then the event may be used to provide customized logic for matching files.
The and events are triggered before and after the synchronization operation is performed, respectively.

member.param: Directory on the local machine to synchronize. If this argument is null then will be used.
Directory on the server to synchronize. If this argument is null then will be used.
Rules to apply to the synchronization operation. If this argument is null then will be used.
member.returns: containing results of synchronization operation

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.InvokeSiteCommand(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Invokes the given site command on the server.

remarks.para: Site-specific commands are special commands that may be defined by a server. Such commands are defined on a server-by-server basis.

For example, a specific FTP server might define a PROCESS site-command which results in another piece of software on the server being directed to perform some sort of processing on a particular file. The command required might be:
In this case, the site-command would be invoked as follows:

member.param: Arguments of the command to be invoked.
member.returns: The reply returned by the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.InvokeFTPCommand(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Invokes the given literal FTP command on the server.
member.remarks:
If a particular FTP command is not supported by , this method may sometimes be used to invoke the command. This will only work for simple commands that don't require special processing.
An example of an FTP command that could be invoked using this method is the FEAT command (which is actually behind the method. This would be done as follows:
string features = ftpConnection.InvokeFTPCommand("FEAT", "211");
The returned string could then be parsed to obtain the supported features of the server.
member.returns: The reply returned by the server.

member.returns: string-array containing server features, or null if no features or not supported.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.GetSize(System.String)
member.summary: Get the size of a remote file.
member.remarks: This is not a standard FTP command, it is defined in "Extensions to FTP", a draft RFC (draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt).
member.param: Name or path of remote file in current working directory.
member.returns: Size of file in bytes.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Checks for the existence of a file on the server.

remarks.para: Not all servers support absolute paths, so it's safer to use relative paths. The path separator should be '/'. If problems are encountered the safest option is to change into the desired directory prior to calling this method and then supplying the name of the file without its path.
The existence of local files may be checked using the method.

member.returns: true if the named file exists on the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DirectoryExists(System.String)
member.summary: Tests if the given directory exists.
member.remarks: The FTP protocol doesn't specify a standard way of testing for the existence of a directory, so this method tries to change into the directory and assumes that that the directory doesn't exist if an exception is thrown. The current working directory is restored before the method returns.
member.returns: true if directory exists and false otherwise

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Protocol
member.summary: Type of file transfer to use.
member.remarks:
edtFTPnet/Express offers two types of non-secure file transfer, FTP and HTTP. Secure file transfer protocols are available in edtFTPnet/PRO:
Type
FTP Traditional unencrypted FTP.
FTPSExplicit FTP-over-SSL which allows switching between secure and unsecure transfers. edtFTPnet/PRO only.
FTPSImplicit FTP-over-SSL which simply performs FTP over pure SSL sockets. edtFTPnet/PRO only.
SFTP SSH File Transfer Protocol. edtFTPnet/PRO only.
HTTP HTTP File Transfers. Currently, only downloads can be performed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.Timeout
member.summary: TCP timeout (in milliseconds) of the underlying sockets (0 means none).
member.remarks: Timout value in milliseconds. The default value is 120000, which indicates a 120 second timeout period.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.TransferBufferSize
member.summary: The size of the buffers used in writing to and reading from the TCP sockets.

remarks.para: The size of receive and transmit buffers.
The default value is 4096.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CloseStreamsAfterTransfer
member.summary: Determines if transfer-methods taking s as arguments should close the stream once the transfer is completed.
member.remarks: If CloseStreamsAfterTransfer is true (the default) then streams are closed after a transfer has completed, otherwise they are left open.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.TransferNotifyInterval
member.summary: The number of bytes transferred between each notification of the event.

remarks.para: This property determines the approximate number of bytes transferred between each event.
The default value is 4096.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.TransferNotifyListings
member.summary: By default the event is not triggered during directory listings - this property can be used to enable this behaviour.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.IntegrityCheckTransfers
member.summary: Control integrity checking after file transfers.

remarks.para: Some FTP servers support the XCRC command, permitting a checksum to be calculated after transferring a file to ensure it transferred correctly.

If this flag is switched on, CRC checks will be attempted for binary transfers. An exception will be thrown if CRC checks are not supported by the server. Also, integrity checks cannot be performed for appends.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ForceConnectModeExtensions
member.summary: Force the use of EPRT and EPSV extensions even for IPv4

remarks.para: The IPv6 EPRT and EPSV commands are supported, but by default only used for IPv6. They can, however be used for IPv4, and will be if this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CompressionPreferred
member.summary: Flag to enable or disable MODE Z compression for FTP/FTPS transfers.

remarks.para: Some FTP servers support the MODE Z command, permitting transfers to be compressed. This speeds up transfers significantly for files that are compressible such as text files.

If this flag is switched on, MODE Z compression is enabled if the server permits it. If the flag is later switched off, MODE Z compression is not disabled until the connection is closed and then re-opened again.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DataEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use for transferring data in ASCII mode.

remarks.para: The default is to use the default character encoding (generally UTF8). Some common character encodings to try for western European languages are Windows-1252 and ISO-8859-1.
This encoding is not used when transferring data in binary mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ServerAddress
member.summary: The domain-name or IP address of the FTP server.

remarks.para: This property may only be set if not currently connected.

para.example: The following example illustrates an SFTP client connecting to a server:

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ServerPort
member.summary: The port on the server to which to connect the control-channel.

remarks.para: This property may only be set if not currently connected.

para.example: The following example illustrates an SFTP client connecting to a server:

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the FTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the FTP client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.UserName
member.summary: User-name of account on the server.
member.value: The user-name of the account the server that will be logged into upon connection.

remarks.para: This property must be set before a connection with the server is made.

para.example: The following example illustrates an FTP client connecting to a server:

member.value: The password of the account the FTP server that will be logged into upon connection.

remarks.para: This property must be set before a connection with the server is made.

para.example: The following example illustrates an FTP client connecting to a server:

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.IsTransferring
member.summary: Indicates whether or not a synchronous or asynchronous transfer is currently under way.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CommandEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use when dealing with file- and directory-paths.
member.remarks: The default is ASCII, but should be changed when communicating with FTP servers that have file-names containing non-ASCII characters

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MultiTransferSleepEnabled
member.summary: Determines whether or not "sleeping" is enabled during multiple FTP/FTPS data transfers.

remarks.para: FTP/FTPS uses a separate TCP connection for each data transfer (i.e. upload, download, or directory listing). TCP ports go into a TIME_WAIT state for a number of seconds after each connection, making it unusable for this period. This means that it is possible to run out of TCP ports when multiple files are transferred in a short period of time.
Periodic sleeping can reduce this problem. When enabled through the property, the connection will wait for seconds each time files have been transferred via multiple-transfer operations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MultiTransferCountBeforeSleep
member.summary: Number of transfers before "sleeping" during multiple FTP/FTPS data transfers.

remarks.para: FTP/FTPS uses a separate TCP connection for each data transfer (i.e. upload, download, or directory listing). TCP ports go into a TIME_WAIT state for a number of seconds after each connection, making it unusable for this period. This means that it is possible to run out of TCP ports when multiple files are transferred in a short period of time.
Periodic sleeping can reduce this problem. When enabled through the property, the connection will wait for seconds each time files have been transferred via multiple-transfer operations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MultiTransferSleepTime
member.summary: Number of seconds spent "sleeping" during multiple FTP/FTPS data transfers.

remarks.para: FTP/FTPS uses a separate TCP connection for each data transfer (i.e. upload, download, or directory listing). TCP ports go into a TIME_WAIT state for a number of seconds after each connection, making it unusable for this period. This means that it is possible to run out of TCP ports when multiple files are transferred in a short period of time.
Periodic sleeping can reduce this problem. When enabled through the property, the connection will wait for seconds each time files have been transferred via multiple-transfer operations.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DetectTransferMode
member.summary: Determines whether the transfer mode in operations involving multiple files is automatically changed between ASCII and binary as appropriate.
member.remarks: See for instructions on how to register a file extension as ASCII, and for how to obtain the current registered extensions.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.SocksProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for SOCKS proxy.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for using proxies.

remarks.para: Proxies may be used for FTPing through firewalls. HTTP and SOCKS (4,4A and 4) are supported.

SOCKS supports both passive (PASV) and active (PORT) mode transfers. Note that only passive mode transfers are possible via an HTTP proxy. There is no facility for HTTP proxies to listen for incoming connections, and hence active mode transfers cannot be done via an HTTP proxy. An exception will be thrown if they are attempted.
Often a username and password will be required to authenticate with the proxy. These can be set in ProxySettings.
ProxySettings is easiest to edit via the Property View.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.KeepAliveTransfer
member.summary: Flag to enable the use of keep alive messages during data transfers.
member.remarks: During very large transfers some servers timeout, meaning that the transfer is not correctly completed. Most servers can't cope with keep alives being sent during a transfer, so only set this property if you are having timeout problems with very large transfers, and you can't increase the timeout on the server. Use with caution - this may cause messages to arrive out of order. Note that the property is used to set the interval between keep alives.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.KeepAliveIdle
member.summary: Flag to enable the use of keep alive messages, which are sent to keep the connection alive when no activity is occurring.
member.remarks: The client only contacts the server during periods of inactivity.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.KeepAlivePeriodSecs
member.summary: Period (in seconds) at which the client contacts the server so that the connection doesn't time out.
member.remarks: The client only contacts the server during periods of inactivity (), or during transfers if is set.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.DefaultSyncRules
member.summary: Rules that are used during synchronization operations when no other rules are specified.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.RetryCount
member.summary: Number of times to retry a failing file-transfer before giving up.

remarks.para: If this value is greater than zero then file-transfer operations will be retried if the given number of times. If the operation has been retried RetryCount times without success then an exception will be thrown.
A delay of milliseconds will separate consecutive retries.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.RetryDelay
member.summary: Milliseconds to wait for before retrying a failing file-transfer (if RetryCount>0).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.MaxTransferRate
member.summary: The maximum transfer rate in bytes per sec. Set to -1 or 0 to indicate no limiting should be applied.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.LicenseOwner
member.summary: The license owner string.
member.remarks: The license owner must be set for the software to function correctly past the trial period.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.LicenseKey
member.summary: The license key string.
member.remarks: The license key must be set for the software to function correctly past the trial period.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.ConcurrentTransferSettings
member.summary: Settings for concurrent transfers. Off by default.

remarks.para: The concurrent transfer feature of ExFTPConnection and can greatly speed up transfers. This performance is achieved by making several connections to the server at the same time, and using them such that more than one file may be transferred at the same time. For example, if a maximum of 4 connections (see is set then up to 4 files may be transferred simultaneously.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPConnection.CacheListings
member.summary: Cache directory listings.
member.remarks: If this property true then directory listings will be cached between accesses. This can greatly speed up calls to and . The directory cache may be cleared at any time by calling .

member.param: Name or path of remote file in current directory.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.Resume
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (put or get) resume.

remarks.para: For puts, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for gets, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ResumeDownload(System.Int64)
member.summary: Make the next download resume at a specific point.

remarks.para: This resume method allows the resume offset to be set explicitly for downloads. Offset bytes are skipped before downloading the file.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.CancelResume
member.summary: Cancel the resume. Use this method if something goes wrong and the server is left in an inconsistent state

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.Restart(System.Int64)
member.summary: Set the REST marker so that the next transfer doesn't start at the beginning of the remote file
member.remarks: Issue the RESTart command to the remote server. This indicates the byte position that REST is performed at. For put, bytes start at this point, while for get, bytes are fetched from this point.
member.param: the REST param, the mark at which the restart is performed on the remote file. For STOR, this is retrieved by SIZE

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.StrictReturnCodes
member.summary: Controls whether or not checking of return codes is strict.

remarks.para: Some servers return non-standard reply-codes. Setting this property to false only the first digit of the reply-code is checked, thus decreasing the sensitivity of edtFTPj to non-standard reply-codes. The default is true meaning that reply-codes must match exactly.

member.value: true if strict return code checking, false if non-strict.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.Timeout
member.summary: TCP timeout on the underlying sockets, in milliseconds.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.Connected
member.summary: Is the client currently connected?

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ConnectMode
member.summary: The connection-mode (passive or active) of data-channels.

remarks.para: When the connection-mode is active, the server will initiate connections to the client, meaning that the client must open a socket and wait for the server to connect to it. This often causes problems if the client is behind a firewall.

When the connection-mode is passive, the client will initiates connections to the server, meaning that the client will connect to a particular socket on the server. This is generally used if the client is behind a firewall.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.IsConnected
member.summary: Indicates whether the client is currently connected with the server.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.SynchronizePassiveConnections
member.summary: For cases where your FTP server does not properly manage PASV connections, it may be necessary to synchronize the creation of passive data sockets. It has been reported that some FTP servers (such as those at Akamai) appear to get confused when multiple FTP clients from the same IP address attempt to connect at the same time. For more details, please read the forum post http://www.enterprisedt.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=2559 The default value for SynchronizePassiveConnections is false.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ShowHiddenFiles
member.summary: Include hidden files in operations that involve listing of directories, and if supported by the server.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.TransferNotifyInterval
member.summary: The number of bytes transferred between each notification of the event.
member.remarks: Reduce this value to receive more frequent notifications of transfer progress.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.TransferBufferSize
member.summary: The size of the buffers (in bytes) used in writing to and reading from the data-sockets.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.RemoteHost
member.summary: The domain-name or IP address of the FTP server.
member.remarks: This property may only be set if not currently connected..

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the FTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ControlPort
member.summary: The port on the server to which to connect the control-channel.

remarks.para: Most FTP servers use port 21 (the default)
This property may only be set if not currently connected.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ParsingCulture
member.summary: The culture for parsing file listings.
member.remarks: The method parses the file listings returned. The names of the file can contain a wide variety of characters, so it is sometimes necessary to set this property to match the character-set used on the server.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ControlEncoding
member.summary: The encoding to use when dealing with file and directory paths.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.DataEncoding
member.summary: The encoding to use for data when transferring in ASCII mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.FTPFileFactory
member.summary: Override the chosen file factory with a user created one - meaning that a specific parser has been selected.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.TimeDifference
member.summary: Time difference between server and client (relative to client).
member.remarks: The time-difference is relative to the server such that, for example, if the server is in New York and the client is in London then the difference would be -5 hours (ignoring daylight savings differences). This property only applies to FTP and FTPS.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.TimeIncludesSeconds
member.summary: Indicates whether seconds were included in the most recent directoy listing.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.WelcomeMessage
member.summary: Server welcome message.
member.remarks: Only valid after connection. May be accessed prior to login.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.LastValidReply
member.summary: The latest valid reply from the server.
member.value: Reply object encapsulating last valid server response.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.LastBytesTransferred
member.summary: The number of bytes transferred in the last transfer operation.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.LastFileTransferred
member.summary: The remote name/path of the last file transferred.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.TransferType
member.summary: The current file transfer type (BINARY or ASCII).
member.remarks: When the transfer-type is set to BINARY then files are transferred byte-for-byte such that the transferred file will be identical to the original. When the transfer-type is set to BINARY then end-of-line characters will be translated where necessary between Windows and UNIX formats.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ActivePortRange
member.summary: Port range for active mode, used only if it is necessary to limit the ports to a narrow range specified in a firewall

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ActiveIPAddress
member.summary: Force the PORT command to send a fixed IP address, used only for certain firewalls

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.AutoPassiveIPSubstitution
member.summary: Use AutoPassiveIPSubstitution to ensure that data-socket connections are made to the same IP address that the control socket is connected to.

remarks.para: AutoPassiveIPSubstitution is useful in passive mode when the FTP server is supplying an incorrect IP address to the client for use in creating data connections (directory listings and file transfers), e.g. an internal IP address that is not accessible from the client. Instead, the client will use the IP address obtained from the FTP server's hostname.

This usually happens when an FTP server is behind a NAT router and has not been configured to reflect the fact that its internal (LAN) IP address is different from the address that external (Internet) machines connect to.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.CloseStreamsAfterTransfer
member.summary: If true then streams are closed after a transfer has completed.
member.remarks: The default is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.ServerWakeupInterval
member.summary: The interval in seconds that the server is sent a wakeup message during large transfers.
member.remarks: During very large transfers some servers timeout, meaning that the transfer is not correctly completed. If this value is set to 0, no wakeup messages are sent. Note that many servers can't cope with a NOOP sent during a transfer, so only set this property if you are having timeout problems with very large transfers. It can result in receiving replies to NOOP with subsequent commands, so use with caution and check your log files.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.TransferNotifyListings
member.summary: By default the BytesTransferred event is not triggered during directory listings - this property can be used to enable this behaviour.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.DirectoryEmptyMessages
member.summary: Holds fragments of server messages that indicate a directory is empty
member.remarks: The fragments are used when it is necessary to examine the message returned by a server to see if it is saying a directory is empty, which is normally used by DirDetails. If an FTP server is returning a different message that still clearly indicates a directory is empty, use this property to add a new server fragment to the repository via the Add method. It would be helpful to email support at enterprisedt dot com to inform us of the message so it can be added to the next build.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.FileNotFoundMessages
member.summary: Holds fragments of server messages that indicate a file was not found
member.remarks: The fragments are used when it is necessary to examine the message returned by a server to see if it is saying a file was not found. If an FTP server is returning a different message that still clearly indicates a file was not found, use this property to add a new server fragment to the repository via the Add method. It would be helpful to email support at enterprisedt dot com to inform us of the message so it can be added to the next build.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPClient.TransferCompleteMessages
member.summary: Holds fragments of server messages that indicate a transfer completed.
member.remarks: The fragments are used when it is necessary to examine the message returned by a server to see if it is saying a transfer completed. If an FTP server is returning a different message that still clearly indicates the transfer complete, use this property to add a new server fragment to the repository via the Add method. It would be helpful to email support at enterprisedt dot com to inform us of the message so it can be added to the next build.

member.summary: Controls SOCKS integration.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ExFTPClient.ProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for using proxies.

remarks.para: Proxies may be used for FTPing through firewalls. HTTP and SOCKS (4,4A and 4) are supported.

SOCKS supports both passive (PASV) and active (PORT) mode transfers. Note that only passive mode transfers are possible via an HTTP proxy. There is no facility for HTTP proxies to listen for incoming connections, and hence active mode transfers cannot be done via an HTTP proxy. An exception will be thrown if they are attempted.
Often a username and password will be required to authenticate with the proxy. These can be set in ProxySettings.
ProxySettings is easiest to edit via the Property View.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PoolMode
member.summary: Determines whether or not the main connection will be included in the pool of connections that is used for concurrent transfers.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PoolMode.UseMainConnection
member.summary: The main connection will be included in the pool.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PoolMode.ReserveMainConnection
member.summary: The main connection will be excluded from the pool.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PoolMode.Automatic
member.summary: The component will automatically determine the most appropriate mode.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings
member.summary: Settings for controlling concurrent transfers.

remarks.para: When concurrent transfers are (and ) will maintain a pool of up to MaxConnections-1 'slave' connections in addition to its own 'main' connection. Many servers limit the number of connections a single client may make to the server, so the number of active connections may be less than .

Interactive applications, such as traditional FTP client apps, can benefit from reserving one connection for user-actions, such as fetching directory listings. Thus when is set to the main connection will not usually be used for transfers. This is not an issue in non-interactive applications in which case the PoolMode may be set to . The default value of PoolMode is where the main connection will used if is not null.

Although it's generally desirable to reserve the main connection for user interactivity in FTP client-type applications, this cannot be done if the server only permits one connection to the server. If is set to true (the default) then the main connection will be used for transfers if it is the only possible connection to the server.
If AutoRequeue is enabled then a task that has been given a failed connection will automatically be requeued if at least one connection is still operational.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.OnPropertyChanged(System.String)
member.summary: Called when a property has been changed.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.Enabled
member.summary: Determines whether or not concurrent transfers enabled.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.PoolMode
member.summary: Controls whether or not the main connection is included in the pool.
member.remarks: Concurrent transfers are executed on a set of connections called a "pool". This set of connections is maintained alongside the main (or ) object. If PoolMode is then the main connection will be included in the pool and therefore made available for concurrent transfers. This is often not desirable in GUI applications where it's desirable to keep a connection available for servicing user-actions, such as listing directories; in these cases PoolMode should be set to . If the PoolMode is set to to (the default) then the component will automatically try to determine the most appropriate mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.MaxConnections
member.summary: Maximum number of connections to the server.

remarks.para: When concurrent transfers are (and ) will maintain a pool of up to MaxConnections-1 'slave' connections in addition to its own 'main' connection. Many servers limit the number of connections a single client may make to the server, so the number of active connections may be less than MaxConnections.

Interactive applications, such as classic FTP client apps, can benefit from reserving one connection for user-actions, such as fetching directory listings. Thus when is set to the main connection will not usually be used for transfers. This is not an issue in non-interactive applications in which case the PoolMode may be set to . The default value of PoolMode is where the main connection will used if is not null.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.AutoRequeue
member.summary: Automatically requeue tasks on connection-failure.
member.remarks: If AutoRequeue is enabled then a task that has been given a failed connection will automatically be requeued if at least one connection is still operational.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.ConcurrentTransferSettings.FallBackToMainConnection
member.summary: Should the main connection be used if all connections in the pool fail?
member.remarks: Some servers allow only one connection per user. In these cases concurrent transfers are not possible. If, however, concurrent transfers have been enabled and the main connection is not included in the pool (i.e. is ), then transfers will fail because no additional connections could be made. In these cases, the main connection may be used as a fallback by having FallBackToMainConnection set to true (the default). This has the potentially undesirable effect of tying up the main connection while files are being transferred, thus making it unavailable for other operations, such as listing directories. In GUI applications, this will result in a less responsive interface.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPLogView
member.summary: FTPLogView displays logging messages in real-time.

remarks.para: Logging messages provide detailed information about the internal operations of the FTP client components. The level of detail can be controlled by means of the property with being the lowest and being the highest.

A context-menu is displayed if the user right-clicks on the control. The context menu has options for clearing all messages; selecting all messages; clearing the current selection; copying messages to the clipboard; and freezing the display. Freezing the display means that no new messages are displayed.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Extensions.AppControl.AppEdited
member.summary: The "app:edited" element is a Date construct (as defined by [RFC4287]), whose content indicates the last time an Entry was edited. If the entry has not been edited yet, the content indicates the time it was created. Atom Entry elements in Collection Documents SHOULD contain one app:edited element, and MUST NOT contain more than one. The server SHOULD change the value of this element every time an Entry Resource or an associated Media Resource has been edited

member.summary: creates an app:edited element with the string as it's default value. The string has to conform to RFC4287

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.CancelResume
member.summary: Cancel the resume. Use this method if something goes wrong and the server is left in an inconsistent state. Not used in SCP as resume is not supported

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.CancelTransfer
member.summary: Cancels the current transfer.
member.remarks: This method is generally called from a separate thread. Note that this may leave partially written files on the server or on local disk, and should not be used unless absolutely necessary. The server is not notified.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.Resume
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (put or get) resume.

remarks.para: For puts, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for gets, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.ResumeDownload(System.Int64)
member.summary: Make the next download resume at a specific point.

remarks.para: This resume method allows the resume offset to be set explicitly for downloads. Offset bytes are skipped before downloading the file.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.DirDetails(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the given directory's contents and optionally that of its subdirectories as an array of objects.

remarks.para: If includeSubdirectories is set to true then the property of objects corresponding to subdirectories will contain the content of that subdirectory.
This method works for Windows and most Unix FTP servers. Please inform EDT about unusual formats (support@enterprisedt.com).

member.param: Use true if subdirectories are required.
member.returns: An array of objects.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.DeleteOnFailure
member.summary: Controls whether or not a file is deleted when a failure occurs.

remarks.para: If true, a partially downloaded file is deleted if there is a failure during the download. For example, the connection to the SFTP server might have failed. If false, the partially downloaded file remains on the SFTP client machine - and the download may be resumed, if it is a binary transfer.
By default this flag is set to true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.CloseStreamsAfterTransfer
member.summary: If true then streams are closed after a transfer has completed.
member.remarks: This only applies to streams passed in to Get or Put methods - local files are always closed

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.ProxySettings
member.summary: Settings for using proxies.

remarks.para: Proxies may be used for FTPing through firewalls. HTTP and SOCKS (4,4A and 4) are supported.

SOCKS supports both passive (PASV) and active (PORT) mode transfers. Note that only passive mode transfers are possible via an HTTP proxy. There is no facility for HTTP proxies to listen for incoming connections, and hence active mode transfers cannot be done via an HTTP proxy. An exception will be thrown if they are attempted.
Often a username and password will be required to authenticate with the proxy. These can be set in ProxySettings.
ProxySettings is easiest to edit via the Property View.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHSCPClient.KBIPrompts
member.summary: Array of prompts used for keyboard interactive (KBI) authentication.
member.remarks: Setting this property sets up keyboard interactive authentication. The prompts that the server will send to the client must be known. For each prompt, an must be created with the matching prompt string and the response to be sent back to the server. Often, a single password prompt is all that is required, and a is supplied for this purpose. For this property to be used, must be set to .

member.summary: Changes the access permissions or modes of the specified file or directory.
member.param: the absolute mode of the file/directory. This must be the base 10 representation of the octal permissions
the path to the file/directory on the remote server

remarks.para: Modes determine who can read, change or execute a file.

blockquote.pre:
Absolute modes are octal numbers specifying the complete list of attributes for the files; you specify attributes by OR'ing together these bits.
0400 Individual read 0200 Individual write 0100 Individual execute (or list directory) 0040 Group read 0020 Group write 0010 Group execute 0004 Other read 0002 Other write

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.Resume
member.summary: Make the next file transfer (put or get) resume.

remarks.para: For puts, the bytes already transferred are skipped over, while for gets, if writing to a file, it is opened in append mode, and only the bytes required are transferred.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.ResumeDownload(System.Int64)
member.summary: Make the next download resume at a specific point.

remarks.para: This resume method allows the resume offset to be set explicitly for downloads. Offset bytes are skipped before downloading the file.
Currently resume is only supported for BINARY transfers (which is generally what it is most useful for).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.FilenameEncoding
member.summary: The character-encoding to use for file and directory names.

remarks.para: The default is UTF-8, but may need to be changed for SFTP servers that do not support UTF-8 (typically SFTP version 3 or below).
Note that this value is NOT used for SFTP servers with a version number greater than 3 - UTF-8 is always used in these cases as per the standard.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.TransferType
member.summary: The current file transfer type (BINARY or ASCII).
member.value: Transfer-type to be used for uploads and downloads.
member.remarks: When the transfer-type is set to BINARY then files are transferred byte-for-byte such that the transferred file will be identical to the original. When the transfer-type is set to ASCII then end-of-line characters will be translated where necessary between Windows and UNIX formats.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.ParallelTransferMode
member.summary: Uploads are by default in parallel mode, which is faster than serial mode. This mode can be switched off if servers are unable to deal with parallel mode.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.UMask
member.summary: Set and get the umask, the file creation mode mask that is applied to the default permissions to create the final permission set.

remarks.para: The umask and the are specified in octal. The permission set of a new file is specified by taking the default permissions in octal, and subtracting the umask.
For example, if the are 777 and the umask is set to 022, the final create permissions will be 755 (777-022).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.DefaultPermissions
member.summary: Set and get the default file creation mode permissions (in octal).

remarks.para: Permission strings consist of three fields - permissions for owner, group and other users. A typical executable file might have permissions of read,write and executable permissions set for the owner, and read and execute permissions for everyone else. This is typically displayed as rwxr-xr-x, in the order of owner|group|other.

Permission strings can also be presented in octal, which has certain advantages. An octal number corresponds to each type of permission: 4=read, 2=write and 1=execute. These are combined to form a group of permissions, i.e. a permissions field. For example, to specify that a file has read, write and execute permissions, it is assigned 4+2+1 = 7. So for the previous example of rwxr-wr-w, this can be represented in octal as 755, where the 5 comes from 4(read)+1(execute).
The default permissions are combined with the to form the final permission set for a new file.
For more details on permissions and umasks, see a Unix text or look up umask and chmod's man pages.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.SSHFTPClient.KBIPrompts
member.summary: Array of prompts used for keyboard interactive (KBI) authentication.
member.remarks: Setting this property sets up keyboard interactive authentication. The prompts that the server will send to the client must be known. For each prompt, an must be created with the matching prompt string and the response to be sent back to the server. Often, a single password prompt is all that is required, and a is supplied for this purpose. For this property to be used, must be set to .

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Extensions.Where
member.summary: A place (such as an event location) associated with the containing entity. The type of the association is determined by the rel attribute; the details of the location are contained in an embedded or linked-to Contact entry. A gd:where element is more general than a gd:geoPt element. The former identifies a place using a text description and/or a Contact entry, while the latter identifies a place using a specific geographic location. Properties Property Type Description @label? xs:string Specifies a user-readable label to distinguish this location from other locations. @rel? xs:string Specifies the relationship between the containing entity and the contained location. Possible values (see below) are defined by other elements. For example, gd:when defines http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#event. @valueString? xs:string A simple string value that can be used as a representation of this location. gd:entryLink? entryLink Entry representing location details. This entry should implement the Contact kind. rel values Value Description http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#event or not specified Place where the enclosing event takes place. http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#event.alternate A secondary location. For example, a remote site with a videoconference link to the main site. http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#event.parking A nearby parking lot.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.FileSize
member.summary: Size of remote file (see remarks)

remarks.para: This property has been supercede by and , to reflect the fact that the local and remote file-sizes may be different when transferring in ASCII mode.
Some servers do not support the command required to get the size of a particular file. In this case, or in case of an error, the FileSize property will be -1.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.LocalFileSize
member.summary: Size of local file (see remarks).
member.remarks: For binary transfers this is the same as the size of the remove file , but for ASCII transfers it may differ.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFileTransferEventArgs.RemoteFileSize
member.summary: Size of remote file (see remarks)

remarks.para: For the and events, the value of this property will be the size of the local file, since it is not yet known what size ASCII files will be once uploaded to the server.
Some servers do not support the command required to get the size of a particular file. In this case, or in case of an error, the FileSize property will be -1.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPController
member.summary: Non-visual Windows Forms component attach user-defined buttons or menu-items to various operations of an or .

remarks.para: FTPController allows the developer to attach any with a Click-event to particular FTP operations. Such components are termed Click Event-Sources.

It is important to note that the FTPController is an optional component whose presence it not required for the other FTP controls to be able to operate and interact. Its only function is to link buttons, hyperlinks or menu-items to particular FTP actions; if desired, this may be done by explicitly calling methods on the FTP connection object.

FTPController supports the following Click event-sources:
Click Event-SourceFTP Operation
LoadEventSource Prompts the user for a file-name and tries to load the FTP connection properties from that file using the method.
SaveEventSource Prompts the user for a file-name and tries to save the properties of the associated or to that file using the method.
ConnectEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to attempt to connect to an FTP server as defined by its properties (see ).
CloseEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to close (see ).
RefreshEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to get the content of the current directory (see ).
StopEventSource Causes the associated FTP connection to cancel the current transfer (see ).

Event-sources are enabled and disabled as appropriate. For example, initially only the Load, Save and Connect event-sources are enabled, and once the client has connected to the server only the Close and Refresh event-source will be enabled.
The dialog-boxes that are used to prompt the user for files may be manipulated using the and properties.

member.summary: The signature of the certificate cannot be verified.

member.summary: The certificate's CN name does not match the passed value.

member.summary: The revocation process could not continue. The certificates could not be checked.

member.summary: Since the revocation server was offline, the called function was not able to complete the revocation check.

member.summary: The certificate or signature has been revoked.

member.summary: A certification chain processed correctly but terminated in a root certificate not trusted by the trust provider.

member.summary: The root certificate is a testing certificate and policy settings disallow test certificates.

member.summary: The certificate is not valid for the requested usage.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4
member.summary: Represents the base class from which all implementations of the RC4 symmetric stream cipher must inherit.
member.remarks: RC4 is a trademark of RSA Data Security Inc.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the RC4 class.
member.remarks: The default keysize is 128 bits.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.GenerateIV
member.summary: This is a stub method.
member.remarks: Since the RC4 cipher doesn't use an Initialization Vector, this method will not do anything.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.GenerateKey
member.summary: Generates a random Key to be used for the algorithm.
member.remarks: Use this method to generate a random key when none is specified.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Create
member.summary: Creates an instance of the default cryptographic object used to perform the RC4 transformation.
member.returns: The instance of a cryptographic object used to perform the RC4 transformation.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Create(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the specified cryptographic object used to perform the RC4 transformation.
member.param: The name of the specific implementation of to create.
member.returns: A cryptographic object.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.GetRNGCSP
member.summary: Returns an instance.
member.returns: An RNGCryptoServiceProvider instance.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.m_RNG
member.summary: Holds the RNGCryptoServiceProvider object.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.BlockSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the block size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: The block size of RC4 is always 8 bits.
member.exception: The block size is invalid.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.FeedbackSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the feedback size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: This property always throws a .
member.exception: This exception is always thrown.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the FeedbackSize property.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.IV
member.summary: Gets or sets the initialization vector (IV) for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: This property always returns a byte array of length one. The value of the byte in the array is always set to zero.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the IV to an invalid instance.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the IV property, however the property accepts IV's of up to one byte (RC4's ) in order to interoperate with software that has been written with the use of block ciphers in mind.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.LegalBlockSizes
member.summary: Gets the block sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the block sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only a block size of one byte is supported by the RC4 algorithm.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.LegalKeySizes
member.summary: Gets the key sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the key sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only key sizes that match an entry in this array are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.remarks: RC4 only supports the OFB cipher mode. See for a description of this mode.
member.exception: The cipher mode is not OFB.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Padding
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm. This property always returns PaddingMode.None.
member.exception: The padding mode is set to a padding mode other than PaddingMode.None.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.KnownHostsManager
member.summary: Holds details of the known hosts and their public keys.

remarks.para: The known_hosts file contains a list of approved servers and their public keys. Setting to instructs the client to use this list to validate the servers that it connects to. Setting ServerValidation to is similar, however the server name is ignored in the validation process.
A single line in a known_hosts file looks like this:

edtmobile,10.0.0.3 ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAABIwAAAIEAt60CtjBMxiOO qgqfFtKZHY3g99uZpuh5E143FTO4dw+EHWNKemoWq59FMFMIZfSLyUpWmsjVT3PP1bc zOXP1OSn967kxLB/w7Xr84B1ZrTLwuR/ilq73HpgO7A8pdEJN7ybprzhs5CBEgaLQo2 pOxfqRYyc8TO2ADnZ1WwtjW48=

The first field is the hostname, i.e. the SSH server. The IP address is also listed - a number of comma separated hostnames and IP addresses can be listed. The second field is the applicable public key algorithm -"ssh-rsa" (for RSA key pairs) or "ssh-dss" (for DSA key pairs). The third field is the public key encoded using base 64.

The known_hosts file normally consists of multiple lines, one for each of the hosts that the client may wish to connect to. It is quite typical for a host to have entries in two lines, so that both RSA and DSA public keys can be listed.

The path of the known_hosts file should be assigned to the property to load the known hosts in that file into the manager. If another known_hosts file is subsequently assigned to this property, its contents will be added to the current list of known hosts. Use to clear the current list.

Server public keys can also be maintained in their own key file and be used for server validation without adding them to the known_hosts file. The KnownHostsManager supports explicitly adding server public keys in this manner, via .
Use to write the current contents of the known hosts lists to a file. If hosts are loaded via the and also by , the combined list can be merged into one known_hosts file by using .

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.KnownHostsManager.AddKnownHost(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Add a hostname/public key pair to the known hosts data.
member.remarks:
Server public keys can also be maintained in their own key file and be used for server validation without adding them to the known_hosts file using this method. SSH public key files have two standard formats - OpenSSH and SECSH. Both these public key formats are supported. Formats can be recognized by their first line as shown below:
OpenSSH (DSA) OpenSSH format as a DSA public key. The first line begins with "ssh-dss AAAAB3NzaC1kc3MAA ...".
OpenSSH (RSA) OpenSSH format as a DSA public key. The first line begins with "ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAA ...".
SECSH SECSH format. The first line begins with "---- BEGIN SSH2 PUBLIC KEY ----"
You can convert between OpenSSH and SECSH formats using OpenSSH's ssh-keygen utility (which by default generates OpenSSH keys).

member.param: byte array containing the public key for host

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.KnownHostsManager.KnownHostsFile
member.summary: Name of file containing the list of known hosts and their public keys that was most recently loaded.
member.remarks: Setting this property causes the contents of the file to be loaded. The file must in the standard known_hosts format. The hosts are added to the current list. Use first to clear the internal list before loading.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Ssh.KnownHostsManager.NumHosts
member.summary: Number of known hosts names and IP addresses that have been loaded.
member.remarks: This count distinguishes between the various names or IP addresses that a host may have. If a host is represented by several names or IP addresses, it will be counted that many times in the overall count. So if a host has been loaded with the name "edtmobile" and also "192.168.19.64", it will be counted twice in the overall count.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPCertificate
member.summary: A ProFTPCertificate contains information regarding an X.509v3 certificate.

remarks.p: Certificates are used in two basic ways within edtFTPnet/PRO: (1) to validate the server to the client, and (2) to validate the client to the server. In the former case, the certificate is obtained from the server. In the latter case, the certificate must be loaded from a file.

Certificates may be loaded from files using one of the following three methods:
CreateFromCER(...) Loads the certificate from a CER file
CreateFromPEM(...) Loads the certificate from a PEM file
CreateFromPFX(...) Loads the certificate from a PFX file
Private keys may be loaded from a PVK file and associated with a certificate using the AssociatePrivateKey(string,string) method.

member.param: Password used to access PVK file.
member.returns: The certificate object (including the private key).

member.param: Password used to access PVK file.
member.returns: The certificate object (including the private key).

member.summary: Loads the certificate from a PFX file, and the private key from a PVK file.

Password used to access PVK file.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPCertificate.PromptForCertificate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prompts the user for a certificate file and a matching private key.
member.remarks: This method will first prompt for a certificate file of format CER, PEM or PFX. If the file is a PFX file it will then prompt for a password to access this file. If promptForPrivateKey is true then the user will be prompted for a private key file of the PVK format and a matching password.
member.param: Should the user also be prompted for a private key
member.returns: An instance of ProFTPCertificate with the associated private key.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider
member.summary:
The DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider is a class that performs encryption and decryption on data without explicitly requiring a password.
There are two different types of encryption. The first type will associate the encrypted data with the logon credentials of the current user. Hence only a user with matching logon credentials can decrypt the data.
The second type will associate the encrypted data with the local machine. Any user of a specific machine will be able to decrypt encrypted data under this scheme.
This class cannot be inherited.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance.
member.param: A buffer holding any additional entropy that can be used during encryption and decryption.
member.remarks: The same entropy must be provided during the encryption and decryption process. Otherwise, the decryption will fail.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider.ProtectData(EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ProtectionType,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encrypts data according to a specified protection type.
member.exception: data is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

An error occurs during the encryption process. Under some circumstances, Microsoft cryptographic service providers may not allow encryption when used in France. This may occur on down-level platforms such as Windows 98 and Windows NT 4.0, depending on the system's configuration and the version of the CSPs.
member.returns: An array of encrypted bytes.
member.remarks: The number of the returned bytes will be larger than the number of input bytes. The method will use the entropy from the property.

member.returns: An array of encrypted bytes.
member.remarks: The number of the returned bytes will be larger than the number of input bytes.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPTransferType.ASCII
member.summary: Represents ASCII transfer type. As data is transferred, line terminator characters are translated into the local (client) platform's line terminator characters (CRLF for Windows platforms). For example, if transferring text files from a Unix server, line terminators will be converted from LF to CRLF.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPTransferType.BINARY
member.summary: Represents Image (or binary) transfer type. Files are transferred byte for byte without any conversion.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFilterType
member.summary: Specifies different types of filters.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFilterType.Wildcard
member.summary: Wildcard strings use a DOS-like notation where ? matches any single character and * matches multiple characters.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFilterType.RegularExpression
member.summary: Regular expressions are of the kind used in .

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPFilterType.Callback
member.summary: A callback will be called when a file is to be filtered.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.LineTerminatorType
member.summary: Type of line terminator to use

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ARCFourManaged
member.summary: Accesses the managed version of the ARCFour algorithm. This class cannot be inherited. ARCFour is fully compatible with the RC4TM algorithm.
member.remarks: RC4 is a trademark of RSA Data Security Inc.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ARCFourManaged.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ARCFourManaged class.
member.remarks: The default keysize is 128 bits.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ARCFourManaged.CreateDecryptor(System.Byte[],System.Byte[])
member.summary: Creates a symmetric decryptor object with the specified Key.
member.param: The secret key to be used for the symmetric algorithm.
This parameter is not used an should be set to a null reference, or to an array with zero or one bytes.
member.returns: A symmetric ARCFour decryptor object.
member.remarks: This method decrypts an encrypted message created using the overload with the same signature.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ARCFourManaged.CreateEncryptor(System.Byte[],System.Byte[])
member.summary: Creates a symmetric encryptor object with the specified Key.
member.param: The secret key to be used for the symmetric algorithm.
This parameter is not used an should be set to a null reference, or to an array with zero or one bytes.
member.returns: A symmetric ARCFour encryptor object.
member.remarks: Use the overload with the same signature to decrypt the result of this method.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Mentalis.Security.Cryptography.ARCFourManaged.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Script.ScriptEngine
member.summary:
Scripting engine, used to load FTP scripts and execute them. Generally, the only methods used should be the constructor and the ExecuteScript() methods.
The setter methods should be used with caution. Typically, when the script is run these setter methods are called to set various properties. This means any properties manually set with these methods will be overwritten.
member.author: Bruce Blackshaw

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Documents.DocumentsListQuery
member.summary:
A subclass of FeedQuery, to create an Documents query URI. Provides public properties that describe the different aspects of the URI, as well as a composite URI.
Documents List supports the following standard GData query parameters: alt, author, q, start-index, max-results, updated-min, updated-max, /category For more information about the standard parameters, see the GData protocol reference document. In addition to the standard GData query parameters, the Documents List data API uses the following parameters. Parameter Meaning title Specifies the search terms for the title of a document. This parameter used without title-exact will only submit partial queries, not exact queries.
title-exact Specifies whether the title query should be taken as an exact string. Meaningless without title. Possible values are true and false.
The Documents List data API supports the following categories. Category: Document Type Scheme: http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#kind Term: http://schemas.google.com/docs/2007#type Label: type All documents of the corresponding type in the requesting users document list. Type is currently one of (document|spreadsheet|presentation) Category: Starred Status Scheme: http://schemas.google.com/g/2005/labels Term: starred Label: starred All documents that have been starred by the requesting user Category: Containing Folders Scheme: http://schemas.google.com/docs/2007/folders/user-email Term: folder-id Label: folder-name All documents inside the given folder for the requesting user

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.Feed`1.Entries
member.summary: returns the initial list of entries.This page is the data you got from the Requestobject and will remain constant. Unless you set AutoPaging to true, in that case: This will go back to the server and fetch data again if needed. Example. If you pagesize is 30, you get an initial set of 30 entries. While enumerating, when reaching 30, the code will go to the server and get the next 30 rows. It will continue to do so until the server reports no more rows available. Note that you should cache the entries returned in a list of your own if you want to access them more than once, as this one does no caching on it's own.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.RequestSettings.PageSize
member.summary: the pagesize specifies how many entries should be retrieved per call. If not set, the server default will be used. Set it either to -1 (for default) or any value > 0 to set the pagesize to something the server should honor. Note, that this set's the max-results parameter on the query, and the server is free to ignore that and give you less entries than you have requested.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.RequestSettings.AutoPaging
member.summary: AutoPaging specifies if a feed iterator should return to the server to fetch more data automatically. If set to false, a loop over feed.Entries will stop when the currently fetched set of data reaches it's end. This is false by default.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.RequestSettings.Maximum
member.summary: the Maximum specifies how many entries should be retrieved in total. This works together with . If set, AutoPaging of a feed will stop when the specified amount of entries was iterated over. If Maximum is smaller than PageSize (), an exception is thrown. The default is -1 (ignored).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.RequestSettings.Timeout
member.summary: gets and sets the Timeout property used for the created HTTPRequestObject in milliseconds. if you set it to -1 it will stick with the default of the HTTPRequestObject. From MSDN: The number of milliseconds to wait before the request times out. The default is 100,000 milliseconds (100 seconds).

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.RequestSettings.UseSSL
member.summary: gets and sets the SSL property used for the created HTTPRequestObject. If true, all requests will use https The default is false.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.RequestSettings.ClientLoginHandler
member.summary: ClientLoginHandler - this is the URI that is used to retrieve a client login authentication token

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Documents.DocumentsFeed
member.summary: Google Documents List feed URI takes the following form: http://docs.google.com/feeds/documents/visibility/projection The visibility parameter has two possible values: private and public. In almost all cases, your client should use private. The projection parameter indicates what information is included in the representation. For example, if your client specifies a projection of basic, it's requesting an Atom feed without any GData extension elements. Currently, in the Documents List feed, only the private/full combination for visibility and projection is available.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.Socks4Context
member.summary: Socks4Context holds information about making SOCKS4 connections.

remarks.para:
At a minimum the following properties must be set:
Property Description
ProxyAddress Address to be used to connect to the proxy.
ProxyPort Port to be used to connect to the proxy (defaults to 1080).
UserName User-name to be used for validation on the proxy.

The following properties should be used in cases where problems establishing SOCKS connections are encountered:
Property Description
PublicProxyAddress Address that the proxy server presents to the "outside" network.
UseClientNameResolution Use SOCKS4A feature of requesting that the proxy should resolve host-names.

member.summary: User-name to be used for validation on the proxy.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Util.Socks.Socks4Context.UseClientNameResolution
member.summary: Use SOCKS4A feature of requesting that the proxy should resolve host-names.
member.remarks: The SOCKS4 protocol requires host-names to be resolved on the client-side. In some cases this is not feasible, so SOCKS4A introduced an extension which allowed name-resolution to be performed on the proxy instead. If this flag is set then the SOCKS4A extension will be employed thus preventing the attempt to resolve host-names on the client. The default is false.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPCommandView
member.summary: FTPCommandView displays all FTP commands and their replies in real-time.

remarks.para: Commands are prefixed with the value of and replies are prefixed with .

A context-menu is displayed if the user right-clicks on the control. The context menu has options for clearing all messages; selecting all messages; clearing the current selection; copying messages to the clipboard; and freezing the display. Freezing the display means that no new messages are displayed.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange
member.summary: Specifies a TCP port range defining the lower and upper limits for data-channels.
member.remarks: The default is to let the operating system select the port number within the range 1024-5000. If the range is set to anything other than the default then ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit.

member.summary: Lowest port number permitted. This is also the default value for .

member.summary: Default value for .

member.summary: Low port number in range

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.high
member.summary: High port number in range

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.LowPort
member.summary: Lowest port number in range.
member.remarks: The default value is 1024. If it is left at this value and is left at 5000 then the OS will select the port. If it is set to anything other than 1024 then ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.HighPort
member.summary: Highest port number in range.
member.remarks: The default value is 5000. If it is left at this value and is left at 1024 then the OS will select the port. If it is set to anything other than 5000 then ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.UseOSAssignment
member.summary: Determines if the operating system should select the ports within the range 1024-5000.
member.remarks: If UseOSAssignment is set to true then the OS will select data-channel ports within the range 1024-5000. Otherwise ports will be selected sequentially, increasing by one until the higher limit is reached and then wrapping around to the lower limit. Setting this flag will cause and to be set to 1024 and 5000, respectively.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.PortRange.PropertyChangeHandler
member.summary: Called when a property is changed.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnectMode
member.summary: Enumerates the connect modes that are possible, active and passive.
member.remarks: The mode describes the behaviour of the server. In active mode, the server actively connects to the client to establish a data connection. In passive mode the client connects to the server.

member.summary: Represents active - PORT - connect mode. The server connects to the client for data transfers.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPConnectMode.PASV
member.summary: Represents passive - PASV - connect mode. The client connects to the server for data transfers.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Forms.FTPLocalFileList
member.summary: Displays a list of local files and directories available for upload via FTP.

remarks.para: FTPLocalFileList is analogous to a , and displays a list of local files and directories available for upload via FTP.
When an instance of FTPLocalFileList is placed on a Windows form, it will automatically detect an instance of or .

If the connection has been established to the FTP server, a listing of the current local working directory will be displayed. Clicking on a filename displayed in the list will cause the file to be uploaded to the current remote working directory of the connection

FTPLocalFileList also supports drag and drop in conjunction with . If files are dragged from an instance of FTPLocalFileList and dropped on an instance of FTPRemoteFileList, they will be downloaded to the current local directory, and the file list refreshed.

Renaming of local files is also supported by the standard single click mechanism, and local files can be deleted via the delete key. A warning prompt is displayed before the deletion occurs. Upload, rename and delete are also available as right mouse click menu items.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPControlSocket.SynchronizePassiveConnections
member.summary: For cases where your FTP server does not properly manage PASV connections, it may be necessary to synchronize the creation of passive data sockets. It has been reported that some FTP servers (such as those at Akamai) appear to get confused when multiple FTP clients from the same IP address attempt to connect at the same time. For more details, please read the forum post http://www.enterprisedt.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=2559 The default value for SynchronizePassiveConnections is false.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPControlSocket.StrictReturnCodes
member.summary: Get/Set strict checking of FTP return codes. If strict checking is on (the default) code must exactly match the expected code. If strict checking is off, only the first digit must match.

member.summary: True if the control socket was connected at the last operation

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.FTPControlSocket.AutoPassiveIPSubstitution
member.summary: Use AutoPassiveIPSubstitution to ensure that data-socket connections are made to the same IP address that the control socket is connected to.
member.remarks: AutoPassiveIPSubstitution can be useful when connecting to FTP servers that request data connections be connected to an IP address other than the one to which the connection was initially made. This usually happens when an FTP server is behind a NAT router and has not been configured to reflect the fact that its internal (LAN) IP address is different from the address that external (Internet) machines connect to.
