member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.Connect
member.summary: Connect to the FTP server.

remarks.p: The property must be set prior to calling this method.

If explicit FTPS has been selected (see ) and is true (the default) then the component will try secure the secure connection immediately after successfully connecting. A secure connection will always be attempted in implicit FTPS is selected regardless of the value of .
If is true (the default) then the component will attempt to log in.
This method will throw an FTPException if the component is already connected to the server.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.AbortAsynchronous(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Aborts all queued asynchronous operations.
member.remarks: This method clears the queue of pending asynchronous operations (i.e. those initiated using the BeginXXX methods). If interruptCurrent is true then any transfer currently being performed is cancelled.
member.param: Causes any current transfer to be cancelled.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.Close(System.Boolean,System.Exception)
member.summary: Quit the FTP session.
member.remarks: If abruptClose is true then the session will be closed immediately by closing the control socket without sending the QUIT command, otherwise the session will be closed by sending a QUIT command before closing the socket.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.BeginConnect(System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous request to connect to an FTP server.

remarks.p: You can create a callback method that implements the delegate and pass its name to the BeginConnect method. The state argument may be used to pass in data that will be passed to the callback method.
For more information please refer to the synchronous version of this method, .

member.param: An object that contains state information for this request.
member.returns: An that references the asynchronous connection.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.EndConnect(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Completes the asynchronous operation started in .

remarks.p: Before calling , you need to create a callback method that implements the delegate. This callback method executes in a separate thread and is called by the system after returns. The callback method must accept the returned by the method as a parameter. This parameter may then be passed to the EndConnect method to complete the operation.

member.param: An that stores state information for this asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.SecureConnection
member.summary: Switches an explicit FTPS connection to secure mode.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to call this method if is set to true (the default) since this is then automatically done when the original connection is made. It is only necessary to do this if is set to false and the user wishes to manually control when the connection is switched to secure mode.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.CancelTransfer
member.summary: Cancels the current transfer.

remarks.p: This method is generally called from a separate thread. Note that this may leave partially written files on the server or on local disk, and should not be used unless absolutely necessary. The server is not notified.
Any asynchronous transfers currently queued cancelled also.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.BeginResumeTransfer(System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous request to make the next file transfer (upload or download) resume.

remarks.p: You can create a callback method that implements the delegate and pass its name to the BeginResumeTransfer method. The state argument may be used to pass in data that will be passed to the callback method.
For more information please refer to the synchronous version of this method, .

member.param: An object that contains state information for this request.
member.returns: An that references the asynchronous resumption.

member.name: M:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.EndResumeTransfer(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Completes the asynchronous operation started in .

remarks.p: Before calling , you need to create a callback method that implements the delegate. This callback method executes in a separate thread and is called by the system after returns. The callback method must accept the returned by the method as a parameter. This parameter may then be passed to the EndResumeTransfer method to complete the operation.

member.param: An that stores state information for this asynchronous operation.

member.remarks: See for instructions on how to register a file extension as ASCII, and for how to obtain the current registered extensions.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.AutoSecure
member.summary: Determines if the component will automatically switch to SSL/TLS upon connection when using FTPS.

remarks.p: If this flag if true and is or then the component will automatically switch to SSL/TLS upon connection. This is only relevant for explicit FTPS since implicit FTPS always operates over an SSL/TLS connection.
The default is true.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.SecureFTPType
member.summary: Type of secure FTP to use.
member.remarks:
edtFTPnet/PRO offers three types of FTP:
Type
FTP Traditional unencrypted FTP.
FTPSExplicit FTP-over-SSL which allows switching between secure and unsecure transfers.
FTPSImplicit FTP-over-SSL which simply performs FTP over pure SSL sockets.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.SSLVersion
member.summary: SSL/TLS version to use.
member.remarks: edtFTPnet/PRO supports SSL version 3 and TLS version 1. TLS is the successor to SSL and should be used unless the server does not support it.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.ServerCompatibility
member.summary: Controls various server security compatibility features.

remarks.p: The most severe barrier to server compatilibilty is the lack of FTPS support on the server. Most FTP servers can be configured to support FTPS, but some only support SFTP (SSH File Transfer Protocol), which in fact is not FTP in the conventional sense. SFTP is not supported by ProFTPConnection.

The second most common server incompatibility problem is caused by differing level of adherence to the standard for how SSL/TLS sockets should be closed. By default ProFTPConnection will attempt to close sockets in the standard-compliant way. While this is the most secure, it occasionally will cause hanging as it waits for a response from the client which never arrives. The ServerCompatibility property is provided for controlling this behaviour. If you experience hanging when a data-transfer is complete then you should first try
and, if the problem still occurs, . If you experience hanging as you close your secure FTP session then you should first try and, if the problem still occurs, .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.ServerValidation
member.summary: Method by which the server's certificate is validated.
member.remarks: When an SSL/TLS connection is being negotiated, the FTP server will present an SSL certificate to the client. s are used to control what the client does with this certificate. The default is .

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.CipherSuites
member.summary: Get/sets the cipher-suites permissible during establishment of a secure connection.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.ServerCommonName
member.summary: The name to be used when performing a name-check during the validation of the server certificate.
member.remarks: An important part of validating the certificate is to perform a name-check. In a name-check the Common Name on the certificate is compared with the host-name of the FTP server that we believe we are connected to. Unless this property is set explicitly, the Common Name is assumed to be the same as the host-name that is used to connect to the server.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.ClientCertificate
member.summary: The certificate to be presented to the server.
member.remarks: If a server requires client validation then this property must be set. s are created using one of the static ProFTPCertificate.CreateFrom... methods to load a certificate from a file and the to load the associated private key.

member.name: P:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPConnection.ServerCertificate
member.summary: The certificate presented by the server.
member.remarks: During the negotiation of a secure connection, the server presents a certificate which may be accessed using this property. The property may not be accessed until a secure connection has been made.

member.summary: Accepts the certificate unconditionally.

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPServerValidationType.Callback
member.summary: Triggers the event which may be used to perform manual checks on the certificate.

summary.p: Uses Operating System resources to validate the certificate. On Windows the installed certificates are used for this purpose. These certificates may be managed on the Contents tab of the Internet Options control panel.

Note that an important part of validating the certificate is to perform a name-check. In a name-check the Common Name on the certificate is compared with the host-name of the FTP server that we believe we are connected to. The Common Name to be used for name-checking is assumed to be the same as the host-name that was used upon connection, though it may be set manually using the .

member.name: F:EnterpriseDT.Net.Ftp.Pro.ProFTPServerValidationType.AutomaticNoNameCheck
member.summary: Same as but without name-checking.

member.name: T:EnterpriseDT.Google.GData.Client.AtomParserNameTable
member.summary: AtomParserNameTable. An initialized nametable for faster XML processing parses: 4 Element Definitions 4.1 The "atom:feed" Element 4.1.1 The "version" Attribute 4.2 The "atom:head" Element 4.2.1 Usage of "atom:head" within "atom:entry" 4.3 The "atom:entry" Element 4.4 The "atom:title" Element 4.5 The "atom:id" Element 4.6 The "atom:link" Element 4.6.1 The "href" Attribute 4.6.2 The "rel" Attribute 4.6.3 The "type" Attribute 4.6.4 The "hreflang" Attribute 4.6.5 The "title" Attribute 4.6.6 The "length" Attribute 4.7 The "atom:updated" Element 4.8 The "atom:published" Element 4.9 The "atom:author" Element 4.10 The "atom:contributor" Element 4.12 The "atom:copyright" Element 4.13 The "atom:category" Element 4.13.1 The "term" Attribute 4.13.2 The "scheme" Attribute 4.13.3 The "label" attribute 4.14 The "atom:summary" Element 4.15 The "atom:content" Element 4.15.1 The "type" attribute 4.15.2 The "src" attribute 4.15.3 Processing Model 4.16 The "atom:introspection" Element 4.17 The "atom:post" Element 4.18 The "atom:edit" Element 4.20 The "atom:generator" Element the atom:icon element the atom:logo element
